facts.text: Two rival factions in Mill area, Nagpur: appellant Khushal and Tukaram (acquitted by High Court) leaders of one faction; Ramgopal PW4, Inayatullah PW1, Tantu PW5 leaders of opposite faction.
Prior to occurrence, number of incidents between factions; Inayatullah and Tantu prosecuted in some.

On February 12, 1956, Tantu and Inayatullah made reports of attacks by Khushal's party; Sampat lodged report at 9:30 pm at Ganeshpeth PS against Inayatullah alias Kalia and Tantu for attack with sharp-edged weapons (Ex P-26).
Appellant Khushal on bad terms with deceased Baboolal, who was friendly with opposite faction leaders.
Pre-meditated murder of Baboolal by Khushal, Sampat, Mahadeo, Tukaram with swords and spears in narrow lane at 9 pm on February 12, 1956.
Baboolal taken to Mayo hospital, arrived 9:25 pm; stated to Dr. Kanikdale PW14 assaulted by Khushal and Tukaram with swords and spears (bed-head ticket Ex P-17).
Doctor telephoned Ganeshpeth PS at 9:45 pm; SI A.K. Khan registered offence u/s 307 IPC (Ex P-1), recorded dying declaration Ex P-2 at 10:15 pm after consulting Dr. Ingle.
Magistrate M.S. Khetkar recorded dying declaration Ex P-16 between 11:15-11:35 pm in presence of Dr. Ingle who certified Baboolal mentally fit.
Baboolal died next morning at about 10 am in hospital.
Appellant arrested on February 16, 1956, in locked out-house of bungalow on Seminary Hill, Nagpur; Tukaram arrested later; prosecution case they were absconding.

Sessions Trial No. 34/1956: First Additional District Judge Nagpur convicted appellant and Tukaram u/s 302 IPC (death for appellant, life for Tukaram), acquitted Sampat and Mahadeo; reference for confirmation of death sentence.

Nagpur High Court (Hidayatullah CJ, Mangalmurti J) on October 15, 1956: Acquitted Tukaram (benefit of doubt: described as Teli in Ex P-16 but is Kolhi, multiple Tukarams nearby); upheld appellant's conviction and death sentence based on dying declarations corroborated by absconding; acquitted Sampat, Mahadeo; dismissed state appeals.

High Court granted certificate u/Art 134(1)(c) on ground of insufficient evidence and error re appellant's absconding (thought linked to liquor case, but records show he was not found in house on Feb 5 for excise case).
Eye-witnesses Inayatullah PW1, Sadashiv PW3 partisan, unreliable; Trimbak PW2, Ramgopal PW4 arrived late; oral dying decls to PW2,19 not relied on.
Injuries on Baboolal: punctured and incised wounds consistent with swords/spears; electric lamp nearby for identification; no coaching.

legal_issues.text: Whether certificate u/Art 134(1)(c) validly granted on factual ground of sufficiency of evidence.
Whether conviction can be based solely on dying declarations without corroboration.
Whether appellant's absconding corroborates dying declarations.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in using absconding as corroboration; per Ram Nath Madhoprasad, dying declaration needs corroboration as not on oath, no cross-exam, possible confusion.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ram Nath Madhoprasad v. State of MP; Evidence Act s.32(1)

petitioner_arguments.text: Absconding due to excise/liquor case suspicion, not murder.

respondent_arguments.text: Dying declarations true, consistent; corroborated by absconding; oral testimony unreliable but not needed.

court_reasoning.text: Certificate u/Art 134(1)(c) invalid as purely factual; dismiss in limine but examine on merits as special leave.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Courts must be vigilant; SC not ordinary criminal appeal court on facts.

court_reasoning.text: Oral testimony of PWs 1,3,2,4 unreliable/partisan; not used even for corroboration.

No absolute rule requiring corroboration of dying declaration; s.32(1) Evidence Act gives special sanctity; judge on facts/circumstances like fit state, consistency, no tutoring, earliest opportunity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ram Nath observations obiter; dying decl not weaker evidence inherently; stands like other evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Three dying decls consistent naming Khushal and Tukaram; made in 2 hrs, first within 30 min; fit state certified; injuries consistent; light available; no tutoring; Tukaram doubt on identity doesn't affect Khushal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reliable, truthful; sufficient alone for conviction.

court_reasoning.text: Absconding not sufficient corroboration needed; defence excuse (excise case) unfounded as didn't leave jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: But dying decls reliable without it.

holdings.text: Conviction cannot be based solely on dying declaration only if unreliable after scrutiny; no absolute corroboration rule.
Dying declarations here reliable, sustain conviction u/s 302 IPC and death sentence; no extenuating circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Haripada Dey v. The State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Certificate u/Art 134(1)(c) not for factual sufficiency.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Nath Madhoprasad v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Observations on dying decl corroboration obiter; case turned on unreliability.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narsingh v. The State of Uttar Pradesh
Baladin v. The State of Uttar Pradesh
Sunder Singh v. State of Uttar Pradesh

precedents_cited.relevance: Dying decl judged as other evidence; no absolute corroboration.
Cannot accept dying decl in part without corroboration.
Conviction on dying decl alone if true.
No hard rule; convict if convinced true despite no corroboration.
Dying decl alone sufficient if reliable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gulabrao Krishnajee Maratha v. King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Dying decl alone sufficient if reliable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chandrasekera alias Alisandiri v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Dying decl (even signs) sufficient if reliable.

statutes_cited.name: Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Dying declarations admissible; no absolute corroboration rule unlike accomplice.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate of fitness for appeal to SC; invalid for pure facts.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed in limine as certificate invalid for factual issue, but on merits upheld High Court judgment convicting appellant Khushal u/s 302 IPC and sentencing to death based on reliable dying declarations alone; no corroboration required.

key_quotes.text: It is settled law that it is not safe to convict an accused person merely on the evidence furnished by a dying declaration without further corroboration...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoted from Ram Nath but held obiter.

key_quotes.text: There is no absolute rule of law, or even a rule of prudence... that a dying declaration unless corroborated by other independent evidence, is not fit to be acted upon...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding: dying decl can be sole basis if reliable.

key_quotes.text: A dying declaration which has been recorded by a competent magistrate... stands on a much higher footing than a dying declaration which depends upon oral testimony...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Tests for reliability of dying declarations.
